channel.title: Science - Digg
channel.description: Science on Digg: the best articles, videos, tweets, and original content that the web is talking about right now

item.title: NASA Telescope Sees A Massive Planet Vanish From View
item.description: "Fomalhaut b" was detected in 2004 but by 2014 it disappeared. How? Scientists think it might not have been a planet at all.

item.title: At The Limits Of Thought
item.description: Science today stands at a crossroads: will its progress be driven by human minds or by the machines that we've created?

item.title: It's Not Too Late To Go On Offense Against The Coronavirus
item.description: To end the nightmare, lockdowns aren't enough. We need to hunt the virus and defeat it.

item.title: A Mathematical Proposal For How To Exit From The COVID-19 Lockdown
item.description: One practical exit strategy from lockdown would beÂ identifying green zones, and progressively joining them together once it is safe to do so.

item.title: The 'Impossible' Science Experiment That Makes Water Climb Uphill
item.description: It's not black magic, but a physical phenomenon called the leidenfrost effect.

item.title: How Does Coronavirus Kill? Clinicians Trace A Ferocious Rampage Through The Body, From Brain To Toes
item.description: As confirmed COVID-19 deaths surpass 150,000, clinicians and pathologists are struggling to understand the damage wrought by the coronavirus as it tears through the body.

item.title: This Harvard Epidemiologist Is Very Popular On Twitter. But Does He Know What He's Talking About?
item.description: Eric Feigl-Ding has been making the rounds on TV as a coronavirus expert. Some of his colleagues think he's unqualified.

item.title: Coronavirus Testing Needs To Triple Before The United States Can Reopen, Experts Say
item.description: As some governors consider easing social distancing restrictions, new estimates by researchers at Harvard University suggest that the United States cannot safely reopen unless it conducts more than three times the number of coronavirus tests it is currently administering over the next month.
item.kicker: A MINIMUM OF 152 TESTS PER 100K PEOPLE

item.title: Why Scientists Are Still Puzzled About The Great Unconformity In The Grand Canyon
item.description: Kallie Moore explains the mystery behind why there's a discrepancy between old rocks, formed billions of years ago, mixed with relatively young Cambrian sedimentary rock in the Grand Canyon and other places.

item.title: Gilead Data Suggests Coronavirus Patients Are Responding To Treatment
item.description: The outcomes in patients at a Chicago hospital offer only a snapshot of remdesivir's effectiveness, but are the first clinical data to surface to date.

item.title: AI Uncovers A Potential Treatment For COVID-19 Patients
item.description: Software suggested an arthritis drug might quell an out-of-control immune response that damages the lungs. Now it's being tested in a clinical trial.

item.title: The Coronavirus Is Mutating. What Does That Mean For A Vaccine?
item.description: Developing a defense against the virus will depend on how it behaves.

item.title: Angela Merkel Explains How Coronavirus Transmission Works
item.description: The German chancellor demonstrated her scientific expertise in a speech where she explained how the country should proceed with easing lockdown measures.

item.title: A Star Is Orbiting Our Galaxy's Black Hole In A Stunning Pattern
item.description: In yet another win for Albert Einstein's theories, scientists report the first ever detection of "Schwarzschild precession" around a black hole.

item.title: What Happens If You Put A Light Bulb In The Microwave?
item.description: The hosts of The King Of Random find out that age-old question: what happens if you put a light bulb in the microwave?

item.title: How A Pudgy Porpoise May Save Other Animals From Extinction
item.description: The vaquita, an icon of the Gulf of California, is swiftly dying out. But its strange DNA could hold valuable lessons for other threatened species.

item.title: What Is Happening Inside People's Bodies Who Are Asymptomatic With The Coronavirus?
item.description: Many people carry the coronavirus without even knowing it. What is going on inside the people who don't feel sick?

item.title: When SARS Ended
item.description: The viral spell broke, and Hong Kong seemed to wake from a fever dream.

item.title: Where Did All The Antimatter Go? Scientists Are Closer To Finding Out
item.description: Particle physicists have released the results of a decade-long search, taking us a crucial step closer toward understanding where all of the universe's antimatter has gone.

item.title: We Need To Stop Obsessing Over 'The Curve'
item.description: The data doesn't tell the whole story of what's happening right now.

item.title: Where Did This Coronavirus Originate? Virus Hunters Find Genetic Clues In Bats
item.description:
Dr. Linfa Wang, a virologist at the Duke-National University of Singapore, has been working around the clock to help Singapore fight this coronavirus. He hasn't hugged his daughter in over two months.

"We're in a war zone right now. Everything comes to me very fast," Wang said.

item.title: Finally We May Have A Path To The Fundamental Theory Of Physics... And It's Beautiful
item.description: How does our universe work? Scientist Stephen Wolfram opens up his ongoing Wolfram Physics Project to a global effort. His team will livestream work in progress, post working materials, release software tools and hold educational programs.

item.title: This Epidemiologist Proved 10,000 Steps Is A Lie
item.description: I-Min Lee gives us the story behind the mysterious fitness benchmark.

item.title: Scientists Are Racing To Get Us Faster, Simpler Coronavirus Tests
item.description: Rapid and at-home tests could give results in minutes rather than days.

item.title: Why The Big Bang Produced Something Rather Than Nothing
item.description: How did matter gain the edge over antimatter in the early universe? Maybe, just maybe, neutrinos.
item.kicker: 'IN A PERFECT UNIVERSE, WE WOULD NOT EXIST'

item.title: The Woman Who Discovered The First Coronavirus
item.description: The woman who discovered the first human coronavirus was the daughter of a Scottish bus driver, who left school at 16.

item.title: The Coronavirus Endures For Days On Plastic Or Metal But Disintegrates Soon After Landing On Copper Surfaces. Here's Why
item.description: "Copper is truly a gift from Mother Nature in that the human race has been using it for over eight millennia."

item.title: Here's The Weird Thing That Causes The Smell of Spring
item.description: You know the scent. Now meet the source.
item.kicker: WISH WE DIDN'T KNOW THIS NOW

item.title: How Medium Became The Best And Worst Place For Coronavirus News
item.description: The platform empowers voices — and misinformation.
item.kicker: THE, UH, MEDIUM IS THE MESSAGE

item.title: Stay Six Feet Apart, We're Told. But How Far Can Air Carry Coronavirus?
item.description: Most of the big droplets travel a mere six feet. The role of tiny aerosols is the "trillion dollar question."

item.title: The Next Coronavirus Testing Debacle
item.description: Four things to know about serological tests.

item.title: What Does Caffeine Detoxing Feel Like? Popular Science Editors Put Their Bodies To The Test
item.description: PopSci editors Jess Boddy and Claire Maldarelli drank on average six and ten cups of coffee per day. What would happen to their bodies if they went off the bean?

item.title: How Much Coronavirus Lockdowns Have Reduced Pollution In Major Cities, Visualized
item.description: The concentration of nitrogen dioxide has dropped substantially in cities around the world since the implementation of lockdown measures to stop the spread of the coronavirus.

item.title: An MIT Lab Is Building Devices To Hack Your Dreams
item.description: From improving your mood to focusing your creativity, scientists at MIT's Dream Lab want to prove the power of dreams.
item.kicker: DREAM A LITTLE DREAM OF MIT

item.title: How Scientists Photographed The First Close-Up Images Of The Coronavirus
item.description: The coronavirus is barely 100 nanometers wide, invisible to the human eye. Here's how electron microscopists were able to capture the first images of the virus.

item.title: Inside The High Stakes New Life Of A Coronavirus Specialist
item.description: For years, âTimothy Sheahanâ was an expert in a field you paid no attention to. Now, he's doing some of the most important work on the planet — racing around the clock to find a coronavirus cure.ââââ

item.title: Why Hasn't The United States Adequately Mapped The Spread Of The Coronavirus?
item.description: Why isn't the United States doing extensive contact tracing for the coronavirus like in South Korea? Johnny Harris gives the history of tracking the spread of diseases and why the United States failed to effectively do this for the current pandemic.

item.title: Working On Coronavirus Vaccine Trials, Kizzmekia Corbett Is 'Not Your Average' Scientist
item.description: A team focused on finding a vaccine for coronavirus is being led by National Institutes of Health fellow Kizzmekia Corbett.

item.title: 'Oumuamua Might Be A Shard Of A Broken Planet
item.description: Simulations led to this new origin story for the first known visitor to our solar system.

item.title: YouTubers Conduct A Very Dangerous Experiment Of Using Dynamite As Electronic Extension Cord
item.description: Please do not try this at home or any open field, for that matter.
item.kicker: WE GOING TO LIGHT IT UP

item.title: What Happens If A Tube Of Pure Oxygen Catches Fire
item.description: We all know oxygen feeds fire, so what happens if a tube that has oxygen flowing through it catches fire?

item.title: The World's Smartphones Are Filled With Gold. That's A Problem
item.description: Small amounts of gold used in electronics quickly add up to environmental and humanitarian disasters.

item.title: What Happens If You Shoot A Ping Pong Ball Going 450 KPH At A Tennis Ball
item.description: Ping pong balls seems fairly innocuous, but what happens if you shoot it out of a cannon going over 400 kilometer per hour?

item.title: Which 3D Printed Bridge Design Can Handle The Most Force From A Hydraulic Press?
item.description:
The Hydraulic Press Channel
held a design competition where viewers designed their own bridge designs. Here's how they fared under immense pressure.

item.title: Guy Scooped Up A Jar Of Pond Water And Left It On His Window Sill — What Happened Next Was Extraordinary
item.description: As an experiment, a YouTuber gathered a jar of muddy water and weed out of a local pond and placed it in his window. Here's what happened after the first week.

item.title: A Year-Long Expedition Spotlights Night Life In The Arctic Winter
item.description: In a ship deliberately embedded in an ice floe, scientists are studying the base of the food web.

item.title: Iceland Has Tested More Of Its Population For Coronavirus Than Anywhere Else. Here's What It Learned
item.description: By Friday, Iceland will have achieved something no other country has: tested 10% of its population for coronavirus, a figure far higher than anywhere else in the world.

item.title: How A Tube With No Pump Or Moving Parts Is Able To Siphon Water Out Of A Glass Due To The Magic Of Physics
item.description: Michael explains the science behind a self-starting siphon.

item.title: How The Fascinating Lever System Inside The Human Ear Works
item.description: Did you know that your hearing bones act as a lever? Here's an interesting explanation of this biological phenomenon.

item.title: 'Human Challenge Trials,' Where Healthy Volunteers Would Be Exposed To COVID-19, Explained
item.description: Advocates say human trials could speed up the development of a coronavirus vaccine.
item.kicker: 'WE'RE ALL LOOKING FOR A HAIL MARY'
